author: mariusvanderwijden
content: For 4844 the price for the data blobs would be stored in the state not the header, so we would need to lookup the state for every block

author: Deleted User
content: ok, in Erigon tx pool does have access to the state, how else would it be able to validate of tx is valid?

author: sky.cactus
content: This would be needed at the "spam protection" step, prior to execution.

author: Deleted User
content: another question is that it can be local and remote

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, you mean for checking balances you have to check state?

author: sky.cactus
content: That was brought up, but we wanted to check in case you all did something special for balances (like store them different from the rest of state).

author: Deleted User
content: yes, to check balances and nonces. Tx pool can read state from core even remotely for this purpose, and it can also have a cache which is kept coherent by state change updates

author: Deleted User
content: this is one of the reasons it took a while to implement - and be late for London HF with it

author: sky.cactus
content: K, so nothing obviously wrong with having some transaction validity details in a contract storage address it sounds like.  This would be similar to if we removed base_fee from the header and put it into a contract storage slot.

author: Deleted User
content: It depends on how this pieces of information can be found. For tx balance and nonce, you need the address to look it up. For this new information, will it be in the fixed place?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.  Imagine storage slot X for contract Y held this information, and that didn't change over time.

author: sky.cactus
content: So you could special case this particular bit of storage, or look it up like you would look up any normal contract storage data.
